page.title: 12Customs
page.content: The celebration of May Day is the strongest surviving custom and is centred in Islip.The celebration is based on the school and can be traced back over a hundred years.It began by children absenting themselves from school,presumably backed by their parents,and taking a holiday.Over the years the event became more formalised.A garland was carried round the village by the children.A May Queen was elected from among the school children,and there was dancing round the Maypole and refreshments.In 1985 Emily Beane,aged 10,was crowned on May 1st in the school grounds before a large gathering from the village.The garland is no longer carried because of the traffic but there was the customary dancing followed by tea in the school hall.Emily was the 61st Queen in line.
